title: Zimbra Collaboration Suite PHP Remote File Inclusion - Active Exploitation (CISA KEV)

timeline.event: CISA adds CVE-2025-68645 to KEV catalog
Active exploitation confirmed in the wild

simple_summary.what_happened: Zimbra Collaboration Suite has a PHP remote file inclusion vulnerability in the /h/rest endpoint that allows attackers to manipulate internal request dispatching and include arbitrary files from the WebRoot directory, potentially leading to remote code execution on the mail server.
simple_summary.who_is_affected: Organizations using Zimbra for email and collaboration, including on-premises deployments and cloud-hosted instances. Zimbra is widely used by enterprises, universities, and government organizations.
simple_summary.what_attackers_do: Step 1: Craft malicious HTTP requests to the /h/rest endpoint. Step 2: Manipulate internal request dispatching through parameter injection. Step 3: Include arbitrary PHP files from the WebRoot directory. Step 4: Achieve remote code execution on the mail server. Step 5: Access all emails, contact lists, calendars, and pivot to internal network.
what_you_should_do: Patch Zimbra to the latest version immediately
Implement WAF rules to block malicious /h/rest requests
Review mail server access logs for suspicious request patterns
Audit user accounts for unauthorized access or new accounts
Check for webshells or unauthorized files in WebRoot
simple_summary.why_this_is_serious: Email servers contain highly sensitive corporate communications, contact information, and calendar data. They are often trusted by internal systems for authentication. Compromise enables email theft, business email compromise (BEC) attacks from legitimate accounts, and lateral movement into the corporate network.

tactics.technique_name: Command and Scripting Interpreter: Unix Shell
tactics.description: Code execution through PHP file inclusion
Access to all mailboxes on compromised server

detection_guidance.summary: Monitor Zimbra access logs for suspicious requests to /h/rest endpoint. Watch for unusual file access patterns and new files appearing in WebRoot.

log_sources.description: Mail server access and API logs
Detect new or modified files in WebRoot

immediate_actions.description: Apply latest security updates from Synacor
Check WebRoot for unauthorized PHP files
